docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''For Cheney and Edwards, a Night of Sharp Exchanges'' (front page, Oct. 6): The vice-presidential candidates' debate was downright good theater, at turns dramatic, playful and inspiring.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Kerry vs. Bush on Health Care'' (editorial, Oct. 3) rightly characterizes both sides' proposals as merely tinkering at the edges. Yet your discussion itself does not target the main anomaly in our health care system: a disconnect between expertise and responsibility.
docs.abstract: Dr Donald Mender letter on main anomaly in health care system, which is disconnect between expertise of physicians and financial authority of insurance decision-makers
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    ''Kerry vs. Bush on Health Care'' (editorial, Oct. 3) rightly characterizes both sides' proposals as merely tinkering at the edges. Yet your discussion itself does not target the main anomaly in our health care system: a disconnect...

docs.lead_paragraph: The Vice-Presidential Debate: 'There's a Fundamental Difference of Opinion Here'The Vice-Presidential Debate: 'There's a Fundamental Difference of Opinion Here'Following are excerpts from the vice-presidential debate last night between Vice President Dick Cheney and Senator John Edwards of North Carolina, as recorded by The New York Times. The moderator was Gwen Ifill of PBS. A full transcript is at www.nytimes.com. The Iraq War MS. IFILL -- Vice President Cheney, there have been new developments in Iraq, especially having to do with the administration's handling. Paul Bremer, the former head of the Coalition Provisional Authority gave a speech in which he said that we have never had enough troops on the ground. Donald Rumsfeld said he has not seen any hard evidence of a link between Al Qaeda and Saddam Hussein. Was this the fruit of a report that you requested that you received a week ago that showed there was no connection between Abu Musab al-Zarqawi and Saddam Hussein? MR. CHENEY -- Gwen, I want to thank you, and I want to thank the folks here at Case Western Reserve for hosting us tonight. It's a very important event, and they've done a superb job of putting it together.

docs.lead_paragraph: More than half the children under 7 in New York City are growing up in immigrant families, and in many of them no one over 13 speaks English well. But a new report released yesterday suggests that this linguistic isolation helps protect them from the higher rates of obesity, asthma, and adolescent risk-taking that afflict native-born and Americanized children. Though the report also cautions that the language barriers make it harder for children to get the health insurance and education they need, it finds that foreign-born children are healthier when they arrive in the United States than those of the same age who were born here.

headline.main: Study Shows Health Benefit for Immigrants

docs.abstract: Report, synthesis of several national studies by David and Lucile Packard Foundation, reveals that immigrant and foreign-born children living in US are healthier than those of same age who were born here; is issued by National Institutes of Health; suggests that English-language barrier helps protect them from risks of obesity, asthma and other health conditions that affect many American children (M)
docs.snippet: A new report suggests that immigrant children are better protected from higher rates of obesity, asthma, and adolescent risk-taking than native-born and Americanized children.

docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from the vice presidential debate last night in Cleveland between Vice President Dick Cheney and Senator John Edwards of North Carolina, as recorded by The New York Times. The moderator was Gwen Ifill of PBS. A full transcript is at www.nytimes.com. The Iraq War MS. IFILL -- Vice President Cheney, there have been new developments in Iraq, especially having to do with the administration's handling. Paul Bremer, the former head of the Coalition Provisional Authority gave a speech in which he said that we have never had enough troops on the ground. Donald Rumsfeld said he has not seen any hard evidence of a link between Al Qaeda and Saddam Hussein. Was this the fruit of a report that you requested that you received a week ago that showed there was no connection between Abu Musab al-Zarqawi and Saddam Hussein? Mr. Cheney Gwen, I want to thank you, and I want to thank the folks here at Case Western Reserve for hosting us tonight. It's a very important event, and they've done a superb job of putting it together.

docs.lead_paragraph: His eyes on a video monitor that displayed the inside of Suzanne DeCample's abdomen, Dr. Lloyd Ratner gently guided a hollow rod through an incision below her navel. Watching his progress on the monitor, he advanced the tool toward her left kidney and then passed another instrument, tipped with a plastic bag, through the rod. One of his favorite CD's played softly in the background, the Jackson Five singing ''ABC, easy as one, two, three.''

headline.main: The Kidney Swap: Adventures in Saving Lives

docs.abstract: Paired exchange kidney transplant operations give people who are willing to donate kidney to friend or relative, but are incompatible, chance to help get kidney; unrelated donors and patients with mutual compatibility swap kidneys during four simultaneous surgeries; actual swap between Jane Thomas, Debbie Barnett, Suzanne DeCample and Buddy DeCample at New York-Presbyterian Hospital/Columbia University Medical Center described; 60,000 people are on kidney transplant waiting lists in United States and only 15,000 people received kidneys last year; many doctors and patients support development of national system for kidney swaps; leading causes of kidney failure discussed; photos (L)
docs.snippet: Kidney exchanges are helping doctors shorten transplant waiting lists, but they also pose serious challenges.

byline.original: By DENISE GRADY and ANAHAD O'CONNOR

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Health and Money Issues Arise Over Who Pays for Weight Loss'' (front page, Sept. 30) makes me want to scream. Instead of using my taxes to pay for corrective surgery, why not pay at the front end?
docs.abstract: Nancy J Smeltzer letter on Sept 30 article contends Medicare and other insurers should pay for gym memberships, exercise classes and nutritional counseling for all people
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    ''Health and Money Issues Arise Over Who Pays for Weight Loss'' (front page, Sept. 30) makes me want to scream. Instead of using my taxes to pay for corrective surgery, why not pay at the front end?

docs.lead_paragraph: When 12-year-old Hannah Scott began middle school last year, she was so nervous that her stomach was not just in knots, it was in serious pain. ''It would start in the morning when I'd leave the house,'' said Hannah, a thin wisp of a girl with light brown freckles and long sandy hair. ''And when I got to school, it was really, really bad. I'd go to the nurse every other day, and be sent home.''

headline.main: How Doctors Help Children Tame the Beast in the Belly

docs.abstract: Estimated 10 to 20 percent of school-age children in US suffer severe recurrent abdominal pain, often diagnosed as irritable bowel syndrome; gastrointestinal specialists suggest that many doctors perform unnecessary tests and often do not know how to treat stomach pain in children; approaches like cognitive behavioral therapy, relaxation techniques and use of antidepressants are gaining ground, but have not been thoroughly tested for effectiveness; University of Pittsburgh study published in journal Pediatrics finds that 79 percent of children with recurrent abdominal pain have anxiety disorder; research on nerve cells and neurotransmitters in gastrointestinal tract is being conducted and supports apparent association between mind and stomach; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: An estimated 10 to 20 percent of all school-age children suffer severe recurrent abdominal pain, and many go months before being treated.

docs.lead_paragraph: Tom Paulsen worked for 36 years as a trucking executive, and when he retired two years ago, he thought he had secured a comfortable life. He had a 12-acre farm near Sacramento and a pension of $151,000 a year, his payoff for years of working 70-hour weeks. Then three months later his company, Consolidated Freightways, filed for bankruptcy and the federal government took over its pension plan. Mr. Paulsen's pension fell to $22,000. To pay his expenses, which include $9,000 for health insurance, he has had to divide up the farm and offer most of it for sale.
docs.abstract: Pension plans of more than 500,000 Americans have failed in last three years and been taken over by federal government, leaving many without health insurance and some--high earners who retired early--with pensions much lower than those they counted on; retired employees of major airlines and old-line industrial companies that are using bankruptcy to stay alive or simply go out of business are being thrown into federal safety net that does not always protect them; federal Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp, which takes over failed pension funds, usually matches payments only for workers who retire at age 65 and earn pensions of up to $45,000 a year; limits are set by Congress; in 1999, most recent count, people who retired early or earned more accounted for 7 or 8 percent of those relying on agency; that percentage is expected to rise when retirees of last few years are counted; workers or retirees can face tremendous uncertainty as their pension plans teeter or fail; workers going through company bankruptcy often have little real sense of how complete their insurance coverage will be; photos (M)
docs.snippet: As many pension plans have failed, somehigh earners who retired early have been left with much less money than expected.

byline.original: By JOHN LELAND and MARY WILLIAMS WALSH

docs.lead_paragraph: Despite laws that ban so-called drive-by deliveries, many newborns come home from the hospital within a day or two of birth. Some quickly return, most often because of jaundice or dehydration. But a study released yesterday found that home visits by nurses during the first 10 days of life virtually did away with such return trips.
docs.abstract: Dr Ian M Paul of Pennsylvania State University leads study on impact of home visits by nurses in first 10 days after newborn baby leaves hospital; study, published in journal Pediatrics, finds significant drop in number of newborns returning to hospital in that time period due to complications, if nurse visits home; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: A recent study found that home visits by nurses during the first 10 days of life virtually did away with return hospital trips by babies.
